title: Wednesday, 25th September 2019
bodyHTML:
11:03 am

Shinshin How does the impeach stuff not just play straight into Trump 2020 campaign ?
BE11:08am

JPMorgan's FX desk.

Grouchmonkey @shinshin snap!
11:08 am
BE11:08am

Surprise! Impeachment risk returns
Late Tuesday, US Democratic Speaker of the House of Representatives Nancy Pelosi announced her intention to
initiate impeachment proceedings against President Trump. This came after a long saga of US impeachment risk as a market issue, which started with the firing of then-FBI director Comey in May 2017 and seemingly
concluded (as a market issue) earlier this year in March with a Special Counsel final report which seemingly
lacked a “smoking gun”.
The latest issue that has triggered this impeachment development has escalated very rapidly, if the shift
by Speaker Pelosi is any indication. It started in early September when the Intelligence Community Inspector
General notified the House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence about the existence of a whistleblower
complaint against the President, but withheld details of the complaint. It was only late last week that news
reporting revealed the complaint pertained to a conversation the President had with a foreign leader, two days ago that Trump confirmed he had discussed with the Ukrainian president corruption accusation against former Vice President and current presidential candidate Joe Biden2, and this morning Trump confirmed that he had
withheld military aid to Ukraine3. Much of the surrounding details remain unknown and we will refrain from discussing the merits of this, or other pending House investigative cases against the President. But the fact that Speaker Pelosi, who had up until very recently pushed back on her caucus’ enthusiasm for impeachment without sufficient facts and bi-partisan support, has now come on-board suggests that developments and the political shift has been very significant.

YourGrannyOnBongos Impeachment still seems very unlikely unless there's some smoking gun that even the Republicans (who have stomached a lot so far) can't stomach. Parallels with Johnson's 'me vs the world' angle
BE11:09am

Key near-term events will be: (1) the release of the Trump-Ukraine phone call transcript Tuesday, (2) testimony from the acting Defensive National Intelligence chief on Thursday4 on the process and handling of the complaint, (3) the
prospective delivery and possible release of the whistleblower complaint and any further details, includin
potential testimony5 and (4) the House judiciary committee taking actual first steps in the impeachment process ...

BE11:09am

"Impeachment is a multi-step, multi-month process that can be distracting and disruptive even if Trump removal risks remain low. This should further weigh on global outlook uncertainty, given so many open issues in which the President is involved," they say.

chomsky hello all
11:10 am
BE11:10am

1998 offers one benchmark for the impeachment process, and should the current episode roughly follow
that timeline, it will encapsulate several sensitive market event dates and could therefore make for a
rather hectic and messy slide into year-end. The Clinton impeachment took roughly four months, and
followed the process laid out in Exhibit 2. Following the initial launch of the impeachment inquiry, it took
roughly two months before the House actually approved the articles of impeachment. This allowed the process
to proceed to trial in the Senate, which took a month to complete. Should the Trump impeachment saga follow a
similarly compressed timeline, this risks being complicated with important political decisions expected to be made during that time – not least of which including the planned tariff ratchet-up dates in the US-China trade war.

YourGrannyOnBongos The political conversation is so bifurcated now, with two parallel groups of newspapers/people screaming 'coup/anti-democracy/liars' at each other
Shinshin Impeachment needs 2/3rds vote, no ? And Repubs don't have an alternative candidate lined up. Trump's on the trail with 'see, everyone's against us regular working stiffs' and gets back in.
BE11:11am

BE11:11am

Wait, sorry, wrong image.

11:11 am
BE11:11am

BE11:12am

That's what I meant.

chomsky The current trump impeachment case and the watergate scandal are quite parallel if you look at the big picture
BE11:12am

Anyway, back to JPM on the effects.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

Markets don't like uncertainty is the top line, as it always is.

BE11:12am

Impeachment proceedings will likely amplify the uncertainty surrounding many of Trump’s most visible
policies of which many have direct global market relevance. A widening of uncertainty over various
potential outcomes, discussed below, could further weigh on sentiment and real economic outcomes through
trade uncertainty and varying expectations surrounding 2020 election outcomes. The exact pass-through from
impeachment proceedings to policymaking outcomes will be debated, and even the direction of influence is not
necessarily clear, but for now we make the following observations on market-relevant issues:
 Trade War: US-China trade is the most visible Trump policy to market participants, and has key nearterm
events that will need to be managed by the administration concurrently alongside impeachment
proceedings. There is not an obvious directional translation of what a White House that now must battle
Congress under an impeachment inquiry means for how it behaves in the ongoing US-China negotiations. But
now it is most likely that key decisions will have to be made around US-China escalation or de-escalation
during the months when the impeachment inquiry will be ongoing, which complicates the political calculus
for the administration and should raise the uncertainty around how the negotiations might proceed.
 USMCA: We have long held doubts about the political viability of the USMCA being passed, given the
necessity of support by House Democrats. Having now triggered impeachment proceedings, the
probability of passing USMCA this year has likely fallen and may not get passed under this
administration. But what is uncertain is whether Trump would allow USMCA/NAFTA2.0 to stay in
indefinite limbo, or might yet again threaten its NAFTA 1.0 predecessor to help force USMCA passage, in an
effort to secure a key economic win and uphold a central campaign promise from 2016. This remains a low
but non-negligible risk for trade policy and markets.
 Trump-Fed Relations: In recent months the president’s criticism of the Fed has become more frequent
and vocal, and linked to various open issues, including currency competitiveness, US-China
negotiations, and stock market performance. Economic momentum into 2020 may become more important
to the administration now to offset some of the political fallout from impeachment proceedings.

BE11:14am

Of if that's all too much reading, have Commerzbank.

Grouchmonkey @yourgranny reminds me of the sad decline in politics in Northern Ireland where relatively sane UU/SDLP politics got polarised into DUP/SF and everyone just fell back to repeating mantras mindlessly. Let's just hope we don't get to bombings and shootings.
11:14 am
BE11:14am

So far the FX market has reacted quite calmly to the news that the US Democrats have initiated an impeachment inquiry against President Donald Trump. That may be due to the fact that it still seems questionable whether this will be successful considering the Republican majority in the Senate. Or the market is torn between increased US political risks on the one hand and a détente in the US-Chinese trade conflict on the other hand and is still waiting to find out which side will create stronger momentum. Or a third possible explanation is: the market participants are sowing true farsightedness and realise that US politics have taken a direction that is unlikely to change even in the absence of President Trump. In particular the efforts to curtail China’s power find support across party boundaries. Our US and China experts therefore pointed out a while ago that the political and military rivalry between the US and China is likely to continue for years. Even if the two super powers
should reach an interim agreement over the coming month there is a high likelihood that the conflict will escalate again sooner or later. This, it is feared, might put permanent downward pressure on global trade.

BE11:15am

That's the upshot. It's better to have the certainty of a potentially deranged president screaming at clouds and doing basically nothing of consequence than have the uncertainty that he'll not be doing that.

As per Numis:

11:19 am
BE11:20am

[New forecasts] reflect the additional interest charge (assume the delayed draw-down notes issued mid-2020) with no change to EBIT/EBITDA. 2019 PBT£17.6m
from £21.7m (-18%), EPS 3.4p from 4.8p; 2020 PBT £95m from £112m (-15%), EPS 35.5p from 29.7p. We see the additional financing as positive, if expensive, with
significant potential as the DBX plan unfolds, albeit a few more positive lines on the delivery programmes will be needed before the shares perform.

BE11:21am

And Jefferies:

BE11:21am

AML disclosed "continuing pressure on sales volume" in Q3 but confirmed guidance in-line with current consensus (£73m EBIT) and guided to £5m additional interest this year. Management indicated there were 806 orders in production set to generate £66m of EBITDA (vs £22m EBITDA in H1 on 2,440 deliveries), suggesting £81k per car of 45% margin on our estimated H2 ASP incl Specials (in other words our ASP est could be conservative). For 2020, FY interest should increase by £14m (£7m cash, 50/50 cash/PIK). FY 2020 capex guided £350m vs JEFe 320m. No update to 2019 capex (JEFe £308m, guidance £300m).

Estimates - No change to our 2019 EBIT estimate of £78m. After £5m incremental interest, EPS cut 50% to 2p. 2020 EPS cut 9% 48p.

Valuation impact negative on numbers but +ve for de-risking - Including IFRS 16, £250m of customer deposits, we calculate proforma net industrial debt of £1.1bn vs equity value of £1.3bn. Valuation metrics arguably deteriorate slightly but the near-term de-risking should help stabilize shares. On 2020 estimates, AML is trading on 1.3x revenue and 20x cash R&D EBIT. Equity leverage could be attractive if AML can reassure on operating performance.

BE11:25am

Okay, so Babcock.

11:25 am
Babcock International Group PLC (BAB:LSE): Last: 565.60, up 24.4 (+4.51%), High: 571.40, Low: 544.60, Volume: 2.12m
BE11:26am

Rally on a scheduled trading statement that says nothing much new.

BE11:26am

On course for meeting FY expectations.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

A thing to note here is that the Babcock story has been pretty noisy of late.

BE11:28am

The sort of concerns previously raised by Boatman Capital Research have been getting another airing.

BE11:30am

And against that we've had some extremely flaky bull theories going round, resulting in what I guess we should call a short term two-way pull. The punters are all over it, both directions.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

None of which has any bearing on the trading update, of course, which Stifel can summarise.

BE11:31am

Overall the group is making good progress, winning work across all sectors with win rates in line with targets. The T-31 contract was the highlight in the period .... By division, Marine and Land are seeing good positive trends. Previous areas of weakness are showing signs of improvement, in particular the South African business. Activity in the Nuclear segment is mixed with the civil nuclear market called out as challenging. Delays in contract awards in Aviation is also called out but overall bidding activity in the sector is said to have increased.

BE11:31am

Outlook statement: Expectations for the FY are unchanged with results likely to be geared to 2H reflecting known contract step downs, normal seasonality and Fomedec equipment sales comp. Our unchanged forecasts show sales of £4.89bn and adj. EBITA of £523m in FY20. This implies no profit growth on an underlying basis (FY19 rebased for various contract step downs, business disposals and exits shows sales of £4.75bn and EBITA of £525m).

11:31 am
BE11:32am

Reminder of our investment case: We are HOLD rated recognizing that Babcock has had its fair share of disappointments over the years, damaging management credibility. As such, we believe it will be a slow grind of change to restore investor's confidence in the equity story. It will take time for investors to shake off the fear that recent challenges are flags of deeper issues. Whilst the capital markets day in June, which set out clear and realistic financial targets, supported by a coherent narrative, was a helpful reminder of the attractive characteristics of Babcock's model management must now show control of its brief by delivering on its targets. If Babcock can sustainably deliver low single digit earnings growth and the targeted £1.4bn of free cash flow over the next 5 years, this can add-up to an interesting investment proposition and, in time, lead to a re-rating of the shares from c. 6x PER currently to, at the very least, high single digit.

BE11:33am

(@Punter: I know it's entirely well intentioned buy there's something that doesn't sit quite right to me about the public discourse regarding what a woman doing her job was wearing.)

BE11:33am

And Peel Hunt:

11:34 am
BE11:34am

Expectations for FY20 confirmed: (1) underlying revenue of c£4.9bn (down c5% yoy); maintaining the operating margin at between 10.7% and 11.0% (FY19: 11.4%); underlying operating profit in the range of £515-535m (down c11% yoy); free cash flow (post pension payment) greater than £250m; and to continue to reduce net debt (FY19 £958m, 1.4x EBITDA). Babcock expect H1 to reflect the phasing of the previously communicated step downs, the normal seasonality and last year’s phasing of Fomedec equipment sales. Our underlying forecasts are unchanged. However, we update our estimates to reflect the recent refinancing. The Group issued €550m (c£500m) of 8-year bonds expiring in 2027. The proceeds have been swapped into sterling, with 50% fixed interest rate and 50% floating interest rates, which equates to an interest rate of c3%. The group renewed its RCF, which gives access of up to £775m and expires in 2024. The bond proceeds will initially be used to pay down maturing loans and the RCF in FY20 and then further USPP notes towards the end of FY21. PHe FY2020E PBT reduced by £5.0m (1%) from £459.9m (EPS 73.4p) to £450.0m (72.6p). PHe FY2021E PBT reduced by £7.0m (2%) from £466.8m (EPS 75.0p) to £459.7m (73.9p). PHe FY2022E PBT increased by £2.0m (

BE11:34am

less than 1%) from £483.9m (EPS 77.5p) to £486.0m (77.8p). The medium term targets set out at the CMD did not include recently announced c£1.25bn Type 31 frigate contract. Babcock will update these at the interim results on 20 November. Work will begin later in FY20 and ramp up in FY22 (PHe FY22 c£200m pa revenues, margin starting low and building to c10%).

Are we there yet BE & @Punter - we have fallen a long way
BE11:35am

a l u a t i o n : We set fair value at 561p, equivalent to 8.0x FY202E EPS and 6.0x FY2020E EBITDA. In aggregate this equates to a 20% discount to the FTSE All Share Index. Our target price reflects the challenging environment in which Babcock operates. However, underlying forecasts now appear to be approaching stability after a series of downgrades over recent years.

11:35 am
BE11:36am

And Liberum.

Are we there yet BE & @Punter - would the media/social media be picking apart a man doing the same thing?
BE11:36am

rading statement guides to trading in line with expectations and we leave our FY19 estimates unchanged. No change to divisional guidance and higher interest already reflected in our estimates. We reduce our H1 FD EPS weighting from 47% to 44%. We maintain our spot net debt of £882m for FY 2020 and maintain our FY 2021 net debt at £867m despite £25m of capex for Type 31e. We increase FY 2021 and 2022 FD EPS by 0.4% and 1.6% for Type 31e. We expect net debt to increase in H1 with negligible free cash flow. At Marine, the business is trading strongly: we expect the Carrier step-down to restrain revenues but not profits. At Land, management guides to slight revenue growth excluding exits. At Aviation, we expect modest revenue growth but there have been reports of cancelled pilot training at the RAF. At Nuclear, management guides to slight revenue growth excluding Magnox for FY20. An average FCFe yield of 10% is simply too cheap, TP 720p, BUY.

BE11:36am

And that's enough about Babcock's rading statement.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

S&P's done its rear view mirror thing.

BE11:39am

Aston Martin Holdings (UK) Downgraded To 'CCC+' On Higher Leverage; Outlook Negative

•

U.K.-based luxury sports car manufacturer Aston Martin Lagonda (AML) plans to issue $150 million of new senior secured cash and payment-in-kind (PIK) toggle notes, with the option to issue up to $100 million of delayed draw notes to bolster its liquidity following higher-than-expected cash burn in fiscal 2019.

•

We believe that AML has reached the ceiling in terms of the amount of term debt and cash interest burden that it can sustainably service, given our expectation that S&P-adjusted leverage will be more than 30x in fiscal 2019.

•

We are therefore lowering our issuer credit and issue ratings on AML to 'CCC+' from 'B-'. The outlook is negative.

•

At the same time, we are assigning our 'CCC+' issue ratings to the proposed new $150 million senior secured cash/ PIK toggle notes and $100 million delayed draw notes, with a recovery rating of '4' (rounded estimate 40%).

•

The negative outlook reflects ongoing pressure on profitability, a high cash burn, and very high leverage in the face of heightened event risk associated with a potential no-deal Brexit and/or new tariffs on the vehicles it exports to the U.S. In addition, AML is about to launch its new DBX luxury SUV, the success of which is critical to its ambitious growth strategy and ongoing creditworthiness.

Grouchmonkey In small caps, any particular reason for the bump down in Scapa, please?
Punter BE et al, guilty as charged I suppose in this PC world, but it was a great brooch.
BE11:40am

What's CCC+? Eight notches into junk?

11:40 am
BE11:40am

nightingale20201 @BE (Re: AML) - sounds like a Short for a while

undefined
11:41 am
BE11:42am

Boohoo. Okay.

Boohoo Group PLC (BOO:LSE): Last: 263.78, down 2.02 (-0.76%), High: 275.40, Low: 255.40, Volume: 2.67m
Upaswellasdown CCC+ (negative outlook) and PIK is pretty rare for senior secured credit
BE11:42am

Interims. Is it my imagination or does Boohoo put out more than its share of updates? We seem to mention it every other week.

VV75 nice to share good news if and when you have it
Umtaliboy2 Hard to see a long term future for Aston Martin when the move is all to ban petrol head toys
11:43 am
BE11:43am

Here's Barclays to say that upgrades are continuing but hell's teeth they're already expensive.

BE11:43am

Boohoo had already provided an unscheduled (positive) trading update on 5 Sept, but today’s results were still ahead of expectations. The company’s performance in P2/1H FY20 is clearly impressive: revenue growth accelerated in P2 vs. P1 (which was itself strong), and underlying operating leverage is coming through very well. Performance was strong across brands, with Boohoo growing +41%, PLT +40% and Nasty Gal +144% in P2. We think there is still some flex to the company’s guidance for FY20 revenue growth of +33-38% - and better revenue growth and underlying operating leverage means they can likely absorb investment into new brands. Momentum on this name is undeniably strong, and we think it is unlikely to be disrupted near-term; but at 42x P/E and 2.3x EV/Sales in CY20E, the shares are not cheap. We are Equal Weight.

BE11:44am

· Strong revenue growth: 1H revenues increased +43% yoy to £565m, c1% ahead of Barclays £557m (+41% yoy) and c3% ahead of company cons £548m (+39% yoy). Growth was strong across geographies, with UK +35% and International 55%.

For P2 (June-Aug), revenues increased 47% to £311m, c3% ahead of Barclays £303m (+43% yoy) and c6% ahead of cons £293m (+39% yoy). In terms of segments in P2: core Boohoo revs of £158m (+41% yoy) were 7% ahead of Barclays £148m (+32% yoy) and 13% ahead of cons £139m (+25% yoy); PLT revenues of £126m (+40% yoy) were c2% below Barclays £128m (+43% yoy) and c4% below consensus £131m (+46% yoy); and Nasty Gal revenues of £26m (+144% yoy) were in line with Barclays £26m (+150% yoy) and c£3m ahead of consensus £23m (+120% yoy). Miss pap/other contributed c£2m vs. Barclays/cons c£1m. Performance of the core Boohoo brand was particularly impressive.

· More investment driving lower gross margins: Group gross margins declined -100bps yoy to 54.3% in 1H vs. Barc/cons -50bps yoy. However, due to stronger revenue growth and mix effects, 1H gross profit of £307m was slightly ahead of Barclays £305m and c2% ahead of cons £300m despite the lower gross margin. For P2, gross margins declined -170bps yoy to 53.7% vs. Barc -70bps yoy. By segment, P2 gross margins were as follows: core Boohoo 53.3% (-130bps yoy) vs. Barc 54.1%; PLT 54.8% (-130bps yoy) vs. Barc 55.1%; NastyGal 52.8% (-620bps yoy) vs. Barc 55.9%. The company has been investing in delivery and price promotions, and the positive response is evident from strong trading.

· Lots of underlying operating leverage coming through: 1H adj EBITDA (ex SBC) of £60.7m (10.8% margin) was 5% ahead of Barclays £58m (10.4% margin) and 7% ahead cons £57m (10.3% margin), and adj EBIT (inc SBC) of £47m (8.3% margin) was 5% ahead of Barclays £45m (8.0% margin).

· Strong balance sheet: with net cash position of £207.4m at period end.

· Guidance unchanged: The company has maintained FY20 guidance provided in the 5 Sept pre-release: revenue growth +33-38% (we have +40%, cons has +36%); and adj EBITDA margin of c10% (we have 10.0%, cons has 9.9%). The company reiterated medium-term guidance for revenue growth of at least 25% pa and EBITDA margin around 10%, reflecting anticipated investments into the three brands acquired this year.

RodneyDangerfield BluePrism, anyone?
nightingale20201 Re: Boohoo = But YOY margins has declined!!!
11:44 am
BE11:44am

The marketing hose is still pointing at PrettyLittleThing, then?

BE11:45am

148% revenue growth

Punter Having been a while back a ratings agency analyst for a decade I submit a CCC credit rating sends a pretty clear message to equity holders about long barge poles
A. M. @Umtaliboy2: aren't they the toys of people in countries which don't care much about the climate?
BE11:46am

11:46 am
BE11:46am

Though the person explaining will have to be a Boohoo, PrettyLittleThing or NastyGal customer and I'm not sure I've ever met one of those.

BE11:47am

Peel Hunt.

Mouselet Yes, but they're manufactured in countries that do care about climate and the regulations of both countries apply
BE11:47am

An outstanding set of results from boohoo, coming in ahead of consensus and PHe. The highlights include the strength of Q2 trading across all brands, including an acceleration in the boohoo brand to greater than 40% growth, coupled with strong performance in trading KPIs, as conversion, frequency and actives show strong growth. Rather than simply riding high on past success, we see strong potential for the existing brands and from the launches of Miss Pap, Karen Millen and Coast. We also note leverage on distribution costs, marketing and administration, the first all the more impressive given recent warehouse investment and growing international sales. Buy.

Ulster Pension Fund Wont they simply just go bust... again. And the cycle repeats itself.
11:47 am
BE11:47am

Outstanding H1 performance. H1 revenues increased by 43% to £564.9 (vs £566.9m PHe, £547.8m cons), with EBITDA up 53% to £60.7m (vs £58.3m PHe, £56.6m cons), dropping to PBT of £51.8m, up 45% yoy. Net cash balances increased by c£52m to £207.4m. All brands performing strongly over Q2. Boohoo brand revenue has accelerated to 34% growth for H1, implying c41% growth in Q2. Nasty Gal revenues increased by 148%, with PLT up 41%. Nasty Gal’s actives are up 112%, with our traffic analysis suggesting the brand is already tipping ahead of competitors such as Missguided. All brands are showing good progress in actives, frequency and conversion. At a group level actives were up 30%, orders 38%, frequency 7%, conversion 17bps, AOV 7% and basket items 7%, a strong suite of KPIs. Group gross margin fell by 100bps to 54.3%, reflecting investment in price at PLT and changes to nasty Gal’s proposition, noting (margin here was down 480bps to 54.2%, but only c100bps since H2).

A. M. @Mouselet: true, true. So they'll become a bit like the 'defence' industry, then.
BE11:48am

Strong margins, clear leverage. One of the surprises is a 20bps improvement in distribution cost to sales to 23%. Originally guiding to a deterioration in this ratio of 80-90bps, this is an impressive performance given the PLT warehouse move, recent automation at Burnley and an increasing mix of international sales. Indeed, while the key advantage will be a better throughput and service proposition for peak, unit picking and processing costs are clearly falling sharply. Central costs and marketing have both fallen as a percentage of sales. Forecasts unchanged, guidance unchanged, but consensus should rise.Guidance, which was raised earlier this month remains unchanged, although given the strength of H1 performance and the detail of Q2 trading, we can see consensus rising towards our numbers. Guided sales growth of 33-38% implies an EBITDA range of £114-118.3m and compares to consensus forecasts of £115.1m and PHe of £120.2m. Reiterate Buy stance. While the boohoo share price is touching new highs, there is still a lot in the tank; we see clear momentum and potential for all three core brands and significant opportunity for Karen Millen, Coast and Miss Pap. Well invested, focused on profitable and cash generative growth and trading on 2.3x sales, we remain enthusiastic buyers.

Are we there yet If people have no loyalty to their local shops - the internet shops are an even worse position
BE11:49am

Stifel.

11:48 am
BE11:49am

We recently reviewed our estimates, which are now inclusive of the recent Karen Millen and Coast acquisition and reflective of the new guidance. We expect FY20 sales growth to be £1.2bn, up 40% YoY, and above the higher point of the guidance (38%), which will be driven by boohoo legacy's strong momentum and the recent KM&C acquisition. In our latest note, we also increased our EBITDA by c.3% to £120.6m, c.5% above current consensus, at £115m, and in line with the 10% guidance.

Valuation. The stock trades at 51x 2019 Cal. P/E, PEG 1.7x, a 16% discount to ASOS. The group is balancing exceptional sales growth with a resilient margin and this should reassure investors about the future of the Group. Buy rating reiterated.

As part of its 1H19/20 trading update, UU has highlighted that current trading is in-line with the group's expectations. In terms of financials, we do not see any substantial changes to our FY19/20 estimates at first glance, except for net debt (in our view, today's update implies potential upside risk for FY19/20). BE11:58am

1H19/20 trading update. UU expects its 1H19/20 revenue to be higher yoy, reflecting allowed regulatory revenue changes. With this, the company expects 1H19/20 underlying operating profit to be higher yoy, with higher revenue and lower IRE (infrastructure renewals expenditure). UU has also indicated towards small share of losses in JVs for 1H19/20. At first glance, we overall see limited changes to our FY19/20 estimates.

Upside risk to FY19/20 net debt? The company now expects a £250m increase in group net debt in 1H19/20 vs. FY18/19 (£7.1bn), driven by £100m pension related pre-payment, the impact of IFRS16 (£55m) and ongoing investment in the asset base. At first glance, if this were to flow through to year-end, we see some upside risk to consensus (£140m increase yoy for FY19/20). UU has reiterated its gearing target range of 55-65%.

JEF view. UU has highlighted today that current trading is in-line with the group's expectations for 1H19/20 and continues to work constructively with Ofwat for the final determinations. In our view, the main challenge that the company faces is significantly lower returns in AMP7 vs. AMP6. We currently assume 3.1% WACC for AMP7, with which we see a 30% yoy drop in earnings and 20% DPS re-basing

UU published a trading statement this morning ahead of its half year results for 30 September 2019, due to be announced on 20 November. Management notes that current trading is in line with the group's expectations for the six months ending 30 September 2019. UU states that the company is well placed to deliver targets in the current regulatory period (AMP6) and that there is no material change to prior guidance on regulatory outperformance.

Overall we see this statement as neutral, with UU on track to hit performance targets. We note that the statement is unlikely to be a key driver of the share price with most investors looking towards the AMP7 final determination on 11 December.

Here's Caz's bullets.

Mouselet Sounds a reasonable destination
BE12:07pm

Positives
 Current trading better than expected with marginally negative LFLs only in 2Q vs JPMe -1%, mainly led by improvement in grocery
 Net debt: Three year net debt reduction target increased to at least £750m, from £600m; Reduction of at least £300m expected in 2019/20
Negatives
 Comfortable with FY PBT expectations (£632m, JPMe £619m); However, Sainsbury expects 1H PBT to reduce by c.£50m year on year due to the combined impacts of the phasing of cost savings, unseasonal weather against a strong comparative period last year and higher marketing costs

12:07 pm
BE12:07pm

Other
 New cost savings plan of £500mn in 5 years (on top of ongoing savings covering cost inflation)
 Bank: stop new mortgage sales; no more Group capital injections after £35m in 2019/20; reduce cost: income ratio to c.50%; double UPBT, deliver double digit ROCE and return cash to the Group
 Store estate review: c.10 new supermarkets and 10-15 closures; c.80 new Argos in Sainsbury’s and 60-70 Argos
closures; c.110 new convenience stores and 30-40 closures; closures to deliver an ongoing net operating profit benefit of c.£20m per year; expect the one-off cost of closures and impairments to be £230m to £270m, of which the cash cost will be £30m to £40m
 Pension: Cash contributions reduced immediately by c.£50m p.a. on average
 Dividend policy unchanged at 2x cover

BE12:07pm

 The pick-up in current trading is encouraging but is too early to call it a trend and has to be put in the context of the profitability pressures anticipated in 1H
 The bigger net debt reduction is welcomed but helped by disposals, hence we remain unclear about the underlying sustainable FCF generation of the business
 Current consensus combined with the phasing of profitability suggested implies a very marked acceleration in 2H, that seems undoable at this stage.
